newsitem.title: USA: ARCO rig to reach Arctic drill site late Mon.
newsitem.headline: ARCO rig to reach Arctic drill site late Mon.

text.p: Atlantic Richfield Co. said Monday it expects a mobile oil rig to reach a new drilling site in the Arctic Sea late Monday, despite attempts by environmentalists to block the journey in the courts.
"We expect the rig to arrive on the site this evening and there's been no interference from Greenpeace," said Al Greenstein, a company spoke.

A federal judge on Friday ordered protesting environmentalists from Greenpeace to keep away from the rig that ARCO was towing from a site 75 miles (120 km) east of its destination. ARCO began towing the rig Saturday.
U.S. District Court Judge Russel Holland ordered Greenpeace activists to keep their vessel outside a moving safety buffer he established around the operation.
Earlier in the week, a Los Angeles-based federal judge rejected Greenpeace's bid to issue a temporary restraining order against the rig.

Holland also granted requests from Arco and the state of Alaska for a temporary restraining order preventing Greenpeace from interfering with transport of the drill rig to the Warthog exploratory prospect in the Beaufort Sea about 3.5 miles offshore from ANWR.
Greenpeace argues that offshore Arctic oil drilling is environmentally risky, and that further new oil explorationshould be stopped.
The U.S. Coast Guard on Monday said Greenpeace has complied with the judge's ruling but that activists kept up peaceful protests over the weekend.
A Coast Guard spokesman said anchoring the rig to the sea floor will take fifteen hours once it reaches its destination.
On Friday, the U.S Mineral Management Service (MMS) approved ARCO's exploration plan for Warthog.
ARCO expects to begin drilling the site in November.
